content: The Act is titled the "Federal Spending and Taxpayer Accessibility Act of 2008" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The Federal Spending and Taxpayer Accessibility Act of 2008 highlights the need for transparency in government spending. It emphasizes that taxpayers should be informed about how their money is used, identifies inefficiencies in federal programs, and points out the significant financial losses due to fraud and mismanagement. The Federal Spending and Taxpayer Accessibility Act of 2008 aims to increase transparency in government spending by providing taxpayers with easy access to information on how their money is being spent. It also seeks to improve accountability in the federal budget process and encourage citizen participation in government. The Federal Spending and Taxpayer Accessibility Act of 2008 aims to increase transparency in government spending by providing taxpayers with easy access to information on how their money is being spent. Additionally, it includes a provision for an earmark tracking website. The Congressional Research Service will create a searchable Internet website by January 1, 2009, allowing the public to access information on Federal earmarks, including recipient details, earmark amounts, sponsoring Member of Congress, and bill status for fiscal years after 2007. The Congressional Research Service will update its website with earmark information as bills are passed or reported by Congress. Earmarks include congressionally directed spending items, limited tax benefits, and limited tariff benefits. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "limited tax benefit" as any revenue provision that provides a Federal tax deduction, credit, exclusion, or preference to a particular beneficiary or limited group. The curr_chunk defines a "limited tariff benefit" as a provision in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule benefiting 10 or fewer entities. The term "recipient" refers to the entity receiving the earmark, and a "searchable internet website" is defined as a website that can be searched online. The curr_chunk defines a "searchable Internet website" as a platform allowing the public to search and aggregate Federal funding for earmarks passed by the Senate or House of Representatives, ascertain earmark totals for recipients and sponsors. The curr_chunk discusses the notification of delay in establishing the Internet website for earmark information and the requirement for reports to be submitted within a year after its establishment. After the Internet website for earmark information becomes operational, the Director of the Congressional Research Service must submit a report to the Senate and House committees on its implementation, usage data, public feedback, and recommendations for improvement. The reports will be made publicly available on the website. No classified information disclosure is required. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on compliance with the requirements of this section by June 1, 2009. SEC. 4. PROVIDING INFORMATION TO TAXPAYERS. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide eligible individuals with a taxpayer account statement upon request. This statement includes the total amount of federal income tax paid in previous years and an estimate of future payments up to retirement. Eligible individuals must have a valid social security number. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide eligible individuals with a taxpayer account statement, including federal income tax paid in previous years and future payment estimates. Eligible individuals must have a valid social security number, be age 25 or over, have filed a tax return in a previous year, and have had a net income tax liability greater than zero. The Secretary must inform eligible individuals of the statement's availability and provide initial statements by September 30, 2014, with annual updates available upon request. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL DISCLOSURE OF FEDERAL GOVERNMENT EXPENDITURES. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must disclose all Federal agencies' financial outlays on the Internet by January 1, 2010. The website must allow users to search and aggregate financial data using different methods and download the search results. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget requires Federal agencies to comply with instructions for adding financial data to the Internet website. Data must be provided for fiscal years after 2008, with "financial outlay" defined as payments over $25,000. If the data won't be complete by January 1, 2010, the Director must be notified. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget mandates Federal agencies to add financial data to a designated website for fiscal years post-2008. If the data won't be ready by January 1, 2010, notification to relevant committees is required. Additionally, a report on the added information must be submitted within 6 months of its inclusion on the website, detailing usage and public feedback. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will publish a report on the usage and feedback of the Internet website for financial data. The report will be made publicly available online. No classified information will be disclosed, and a Government Accountability Office report on compliance is due by January 1, 2011.
